Moc_Proc: The Spanish are savage invaders. Do not trust them. They smell bad and their small minds only believe in 1 God. .
XY_Statement: We do not know their intentions. We should go out to meet them instead of fighting. It may give us a chance to make an ally against the Aztecs.
XE_Statement: Since we don't know their intentions, we aren't sure if they are allied with the Mexica or will challenge them. We should wait and see. If they challenge the Aztecs, this could be our chance to be rid of the Aztec threat.
Max_Statement: All people should reviewed and considered before any hasty decision be made. Whether they be allies or enemies, all shall be known in due time. For now, let us withhold any malice until their intentions become clear to us. Hail Camaxtli.

Marina.passage: Spaniards defeat the Tlaxcalans in battle

Xicotencatl_Elder.passage: Spaniards and Tlaxcalans on the way to Cholula

Xicotencatl_Younger.passage: Spaniards and Tlaxcalans on the way to Cholula

Maxixcatl.passage: Spaniards and Tlaxcalans on the way to Cholula

passageHistory.The Library:
It's eight weeks into the semester and you're already drowning in work. You have your first exams this week, you need to get started on some research, and now your history professor has sprung a surprise assignment on you at the last minute—and it's due tomorrow! The only way you're going to get everything done is to pull an all-nighter. There's no way you'll be able to stay awake at home; your bed is there and it's just too tempting. So you head to the library.

It's 7 pm and the library is more crowded than usual. It looks like you're not the only one with a mountain of work to do this week! There's no way you'll be able to focus in the midst of so many people. Maybe the top floor is quieter. You head upstairs towards the study carrels, but they're all taken. It's dead quiet up here, but there's nowhere to work. You begin wandering down unfamiliar hallways, poking your head into all the different rooms, but none of them work. You're beginning to get frustrated when you notice a door you've never seen before. It's tucked into an alcove in the very back corner of the building. You decide to check this one last spot before you give up and join the masses downstairs.

The door sticks as you try to open it, but you can tell it's not locked. You give it a pull and it creaks open, revealing a tiny room piled high with books and a single, overstuffed chair. There's not a soul to be found. When you close the door behind you, you can't even hear the sound of the H-VAC that hums through the rest of the building. This is perfect. You can't believe your luck!

You unload your books and make yourself comfortable—maybe a little too comfortable. You get to work on your assignment, but within a matter of minutes your eyes get heavy. You struggle to stay awake but it's impossible to focus. Maybe a ten-minute nap will help. You tell yourself that if you just get it out of your system, you'll be good to go for the rest of the night. You close your eyes and quickly slip into a deep sleep.

Suddenly, you're startled by a loud noise!
passageHistory.Character assignment and points selectio:
You open your eyes and find yourself staring out a window at the night sky. The noise you heard was the distant rumble of thunder.

You are momentarily disoriented, but this passes quickly as you realize that you somehow know exactly where—and who—you are. You are Xicotencatl the Elder, the wizened leader of the Tlaxcalan confederation. You have long held power, but you know your days will soon come to an end and you fear what may come to pass in your absence.

You lie on your mat upon the floor listening to the thunder, unsettled by a very clear sense that something is about to happen. For now, you have no choice but to wait for the Gods to reveal their plan. In the meantime, you must complete a small task.

Use the counter below to develop your character. You have 20 points, which you may distribute however you choose between qualities: strength, loyalty, and wisdom. These qualities will be important in the days to come, so choose wisely.




You need to assign points to your character to continue.
Are you ready to begin your journey?
passageHistory.Quest intro: The Tlaxcalan Legend of Que:
You must wait for enough players to gather to begin.

2 Spanish players have joined the game. You must have at least 3 active players.

5 Aztec players have joined the game. You must have at least 3 active players.

1 Tlaxcalan players have joined the game. You must have at least 2 active players.
passageHistory.Quest: Tlaxcalan instructions:
Before you can begin your quest, you must choose a teammate to lead your people.

You choose:

Xicotencatl the Younger.

Maxixcatl.
passageHistory.Scavenger Hunt Hub:
Click each of the following glyphs to visit key sites around the Aztec Empire. Once you have read the clue and figured out your location, your quest leader must enter the name of the place into the text box provided. When you have obtained enough resources to survive your journey, you will be given the location of Quetzalcoatl's heart.

Remember: You must enter the proper Nahuatl name and you must use the correct spelling! The text box will remain available until you enter the correct response.

Your team has accumulated 0 points.













Your team has accumulated 0 points.

You cannot yet travel to Cholula, continue your quest to gather all the items necessary to travel.
passageHistory.Xochimilco:
If you are to survive your journey, you will need to stop first at the place of flowers. Be careful as you seek what you came for, as you could easily get stuck in the mud.

Maxixcatl must answer this question. Please work on the discussion board to help him solve the riddle. When he has input the answer, see if you've solved the puzzle
passageHistory.Xochimilco 2:
choula

Your answer is incorrect. You may try again, or you may return to the palace and try another quest.
passageHistory.Cholula:
You've made it to Cholula!

Congratulations! You have beaten the Mexica. But only Maxixcatl can claim Quetzalcoatl's heart. Let's hope he does it before the Mexica arrive, because this prize will increase your teams's strength by 5!

This is the end of your quest.
passageHistory.End of Quest: Now that your quest is complete, you return home exhausted. After all that excitement, you hope to get some rest in the coming days.
passageHistory.Tlaxcalans hear rumors of strange men on:
You return from your journey to find the village buzzing with news. One of your spies has just returned from the coast, where a band of strangers recently arrived from across the sea. The strangers are pale in skin and covered in hair. They have been giving gifts to people of the coast and winning their affection. These coastal people are allied to the Mexica, but have been brutalized by them. Like so many others in the empire, they harbor deep resentment for their Aztec overlords.

Rumor has it that the strangers have been warned about the Mexica, but show little fear. They have asked many questions about the Aztec capital of Tenochtitlán and how they might reach it.

Go to the Tlaxcalan discussion board and discuss amongst yourselves how you feel about this news.

You may:

1. Do nothing.

2. Venture into Tenochtitlan and meet with Moctezuma. Maybe you can come to some sort of truce.

or

3. Go to the coast and try to learn more as spies.
passageHistory.Tlaxcala sends spies to Veracruz:
You disguise yourselves as Huastec traders, and you head to the coast of Veracruz. There, you observe the meeting of the Mexica and the bearded strangers from afar.

You watch a friendly meeting between your enemies and the strangers.
passageHistory.On a Beach in Veracruz: Gifts:
Your spies have been busy keeping watch over events along the coast and they have many stories to tell. It seems a delegation of Mexica went in search of the strangers who arrived by sea and warned them not to make the journey to Tennochtitlán. The Mexica plied the strange men with gifts, laying at their feet a small mountain of treasures, from coveted cotton cloth to the finest quetzal plumes. The foreigners appeared very impressed, but paid little heed to the Mexica's warnings. They have requested a meeting with the Emperor Moctezuma. The local people have informed your spies that the leader of the foreigners seems determined to make the journey inland.

You will continue to observe these developments closely as you consider your next move. Given all that you have learned so far, what do you make of these events? What might the arrival of these strangers mean for your people?

Tlaxcalans observe the Spanish ships being destroyed
passageHistory.Tlaxcalans observe the Spanish ships bei:
You have continued to observe events along the coast, waiting to see what this strange turn of events will mean for you. The news that arrives next is intriguing.

Your spies have witnessed turmoil among the foreigners. Their leader was seen moving their canoes to land and when the other men saw what he had done, they were clearly angry. There seems to be a good deal of conflict among them and you wonder what this could mean. Should you take advantage of this moment to act? And if so, how? Who is the bigger threat in this moment: the Mexica or the strangers on the coast?

Go to the Tlaxcalan discussion board and decide upon your best course of action. You can decide as a group to:

do nothing,

attack the Spaniards on the beach,

or you can attack the Mexica on their way back to Tenochtitlan.
